bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to H.D. Bruns, March 30, 1922

div1.p: Carter asks Bruns about mosquito breeding in puddles with mud sides.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to H.D. Bruns, March 30, 1922
div1.opener:
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
March 30, 1922.
/LC
Dr. H. D. Bruns,
Camp Street,
New Orleans, La.
Dear Doctor Bruns:
div1.p:
In your contribution to Augustin's Hostory of Yellow Fever you state
that you found Stegomyia breeding yourself in pools and gutters.

1/ If you could satisfy yourself that the eggs or larvae had not
washed down in these places--say from house gutters, or possibly overflow-
ed cisterns?

2/ Not a few street gutters in New Orleans have a cypress plank on
the side. Could you, at this date, recall, if these places had such wood-
en sides?

The reason I am asking this is because neither in Panama: Havana:
Peru or Guayaquil have any of our workers ever found Stegomyia breeding
completely--that is from egg to imago--in any collection of water with
mud sides. This is the statement of LePrince (Havana and Panama): Connor
at Guayaquil: Hanson in Peru: Caldwell in Vera Cruz: and has certainly
been my own experience.

In Panama a reward of $50.00 was offered for any Stegomyia larvae
found in puddles--not washed or poured in. It was never claimed.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Address:
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
